item.title: African Development Bank Elects Mauritania’s Tah as President
item.description: The African Development Bank elected Sidi Ould Tah as its new president, installing a former Mauritanian finance minister at the helm of one of the most important multilateral institutions on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije

media:content.media:description: Sidi Ould Tah following his election as president of the African Development Bank in Abidjan, on May 29.

item.title: Mandy on $1B Dollar to buy Hailey Bieber's Rhode Brand
item.description: E.l.f. Beauty announcing it will buy Hailey Bieber's brand, Rhode for $1 billion dollars. The move gives the cosmetics retailer access to a product line that has become hugely popular among Gen Z and millennials. E.l.f Beauty CFO Mandy Fields joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the deal. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: European Gas Slides as Demand Worries Linger After Tariff Ruling
item.description: European natural gas declined amid persistent demand concerns, despite a US court decision to block President Donald Trump’s sweeping global tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

media:content.media:description: An LNG storage and distribution facility in Spain. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: United, JetBlue Partner to Integrate NYC Area Operations
item.description: United Airlines Holdings Inc. and JetBlue Airways Corp. agreed to a partnership that allows travelers to use loyalty points and book flights across the two carriers and integrates the airlines’ operations in the New York City area. George Ferguson of Bloomberg Intelligence has more on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: US Stocks Trim Earlier Gains With Trump to Appeal on Tariffs
item.description: US stocks pared gains in midday trading Thursday — and briefly turned negative — after the White House doubled down on its plans to purse tariffs despite a legal blow to its recent policies.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: Telegram Raises $1.7 Billion Convertible Bond for Debt Swap
item.description: Telegram raised $1.7 billion from convertible bonds that it will use to retire existing debt and lengthen the maturity of its debt.
item.dc:creator: Olga Voitova

item.title: Stock Rally Fades on Tariff Jitters as Bonds Climb: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street traders cheering solid results from Nvidia Corp. had to face the harsh reality of slowing economic data as well as legal uncertainties around President Donald Trump’s trade war.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Cleo Capital Managing Director Sarah Kunst says Nvidia's Jensen Huang is the "best-suited CEO" to deal with the recent US-China trade tensions on "Bloomberg The Close." Nvidia said sales will be about $45 billion in the second fiscal quarter. That included the loss of roughly $8 billion in revenue from China because of export controls.

item.title: Gold Rebounds as Dollar Gives Up Gains From Trump Tariffs Ruling
item.description: Gold rose as the dollar gave up short-lived gains on a court ruling against President Donald Trump’s global tariffs agenda.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Yvonne Yue Li

item.title: Oil Declines as OPEC+ Supply Concerns Overshadow Tariff Relief
item.description: Oil declined as soft US economic data and concerns about rising supplies eroded the risk-on sentiment from a court ruling that blocked a swath of the Trump administration’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

item.title: Tesla Set to Launch Robotaxi in Austin on June 12
item.description: Tesla is set to launch its robotaxi service in Austin on June 12, a milestone in Elon Musk's plan to reshape the company around driverless vehicles and artificial intelligence. Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow broke the story and reports on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Burkina Faso Sees Restart of Gold Mines Boosting Output in 2025
item.description: Burkina Faso is poised to increase its industrial gold mining this year as a project by Mauritius’s Soleil Resources International Ltd. rises to full production and a new mine by Australia’s West African Resources Ltd. starts output later this year.
item.dc:creator: Tanga Kafando

media:content.media:description: A digger operates at the Fimiston Open Pit gold mine, known as the Super Pit, operated by Kalgoorlie Consolidated Gold Mines Ltd. (KCGM), in Kalgoorlie-Boulder, Western Australia, Australia, on Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024. Gold endured a volatile ride Monday, dropping sharply and then recovering as traders assessed a brutal stocks selloff and Middle East tensions. Photographer: Carla Gottgens/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed Might Not Cut Rates This Year, Goldman's Kaplan Says
item.description: Goldman Sachs Vice Chair Robert Kaplan, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, says he expects sluggish growth but not a recession. Speaking with Sonali Basak at the Goldman Sachs Tenth Annual Leveraged Finance and Credit Conference in Dana Point, California, Kaplan also discusses the outlook for Fed monetary policy this year. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Mortgage Rates Rise for a Third Time While Sticking Below 7%
item.description: Mortgage rates in the US rose for a third straight week.
item.dc:creator: Prashant Gopal

media:content.media:description: Homes in Hercules, California, US, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. The Mortgage Bankers Association is scheduled to release mortgage applications figures on March 26.

item.title: Cocoa Extends Drop on US Tariff Ruling, Improved Crop Prospects
item.description: Cocoa hit its longest losing streak in nearly three years after the US trade court’s decision to block the vast majority of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs added to bearish momentum.
item.dc:creator: Mumbi Gitau

media:content.media:description: Chocolate. Photographer: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images North America

item.title: David Einhorn Says US Should Prep for ‘Punch in the Face’
item.description: Greenlight Capital Inc. founder David Einhorn said he’s wary about the US’ ability to withstand the effects of a trade war with China and is neutral on US stocks overall.
item.dc:creator: Chunzi Xu, Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: David Einhorn, portfolio manager and co-founder of Greenlight Capital LLC, during an interview for an episode of Bloomberg Wealth with David Rubenstein in New York, US, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. Einhorn called tariffs “a regressive tax” that will force the US Federal Reserve to act, as President Donald Trump’s higher-than-expected global tariffs shocked investors and sent markets tumbling.

item.title: Fed's Goolsbee Says US Going in 'Stagflationary Direction'
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Austan Goolsbee says the US is going in a "stagflationary direction" but it is not the stagflation of the 1970s during a moderated discussion in Mackinac Island, Michigan. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Juicy Carry Is Fueling a ‘Pain Trade’ for Colombia Peso Bears
item.description: Slumping oil prices, a widening budget deficit and a leftist leader pushing for lower interest rates: At first glance, it’s the perfect setup for currency traders to bet against Colombia.
item.dc:creator: Nicolle Yapur, Vinicius Andrade

item.title: Michael Cembalest on Why AI Is the Stock Market Bet of the Century
item.description: A chat with JPMorgan Asset Management's cult analyst.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang, co-founder and chief executive officer of Nvidia Corp., during the Computex conference in Taipei, Taiwan, on Monday, May 19, 2025. Nvidia unveiled the latest raft of technologies aimed at sustaining the boom in demand for AI computing — and ensuring that its products stay at the center of the action. Photographer: Annabelle Chih/Bloomberg

item.title: Odd Lots: Michael Cembalest Says AI Is Bet of Century (Podcast)
item.description: Michael Cembalest has been an investment analyst for almost 40 years and his research notes have drawn a cult following on Wall Street. He’s known for going super deep into a wide range of topics, like energy and healthcare. And lately he’s been writing a lot about AI, with a particular interest in figuring out whether all the investment in data centers and compute will translate into actual profits. On this episode, we talk to the chair of market and investment strategy for JPMorgan Asset Manag
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Fed’s Goolsbee Sees Lower Interest Rates If Tariffs Fade Away
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Austan Goolsbee said a resolution in trade policy could push the US economy back toward its pre-tariff trajectory, allowing officials to lower interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 5/29/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Spain Blackout Blame Game Heats Up as Iberdrola Points to Grid
item.description: Spain’s grid operator and the country’s largest utility took to public finger-wagging over their roles during the country’s biggest-ever blackout.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: An unlit residential street with no street lighting during power outage in Molins de Rei, Spain, Spain, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Spain and Portugal lost power shortly after 12:30 p.m. local time in a massive blackout that idled public transport, airports and phone services, bringing the daily activities of millions to a halt.

item.title: Egypt Considers Securing Another LNG Vessel as Import Needs Jump
item.description: Egypt is considering adding yet another LNG import vessel, according to people familiar with the plan, as the nation that was exporting gas just a year ago is now rushing to lock in supplies to cover domestic demand.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Liao, Salma El Wardany

media:content.media:description: Women observe the Tenaga Satu, a Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) tanker owned by MISC Berhad, a Malaysian shipping company, as it sails northbound on the Suez Canal in Ismailia, Egypt, on Tuesday, Dec. 11, 2007. Egypt will raise the cost of crossing the Suez Canal by an average of 7.1 percent starting in April to take advantage of an increase in seaborne trade from Asia. Photographer: DANA SMILLIE

item.title: Kazakhstan Defies OPEC+ Ahead of Meeting on New Supply Hike
item.description: Kazakhstan said it can’t cut oil production and even hopes to increase output beyond planned levels later this year, deepening a stand-off with OPEC+ before the group meets this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Nariman Gizitdinov, Grant Smith

media:content.media:description: A pumping unit draws oil at a field in Kazakhstan.

item.title: Tropical Depression in Pacific Is Heading Toward Baja, California
item.description: Tropical Storm Alvin has formed off Mexico’s Pacific Coast, becoming the first named system in the western hemisphere this year as it churns north toward Baja California.
item.dc:creator: Brian K Sullivan

media:content.media:description: A tropical depression forming off Mexico’s Pacific Coast on May 28, 2025.

item.title: Apollo Teams Up With JPMorgan, Goldman to Trade Private Credit
item.description: Apollo Global Management Inc. is working with JPMorgan Chase & Co., Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and three other banks to trade private credit, partnering with Wall Street’s largest firms to syndicate investment-grade debt on a broader scale.
item.dc:creator: Laura Benitez

media:content.media:description: The Apollo Global Management LLC office in New York.

item.title: Advertising in the Age of AI with Vaynerchuk
item.description: Gary Vaynerchuck, Vaynermedia CEO speaks with Scarlet Fu and Alix Steel about the future of advertising in the age of AI. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Economists Are Ever More Gloomy About Colombia’s Fiscal Outlook
item.description: Colombian economists are increasingly gloomy about the nation’s fiscal outlook, with some predicting the biggest deficit since the pandemic this year.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

item.title: Consumer Weakness Starting to Hit Travel, MoneyGram CEO Warns
item.description: The CEO of the international money transfer firm MoneyGram says the consumer is starting to feel stressed, especially when it comes to travel spending. Bloomberg's Sonali Basak caught up with Anthony Soohoo, the CEO of the company at the Goldman Sachs Leveraged Finance Conference in California. They talked about the impact of tariffs and when MoneyGram might go public again. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Jack Mallers Aims to One-Up Michael Saylor With Tether and Cantor’s Help
item.description: Until recently, Jack Mallers was probably best known outside the hardcore crypto community for bursting into tears in 2021 while announcing that Bitcoin would be legal tender in El Salvador during the industry’s largest conference in Miami.
item.dc:creator: Teresa Xie
